												Note: If your biggest problem with TrackMania Turbo is the Uplay implementation, stop reading now. I'm not a fan either, but this review will do nothing to challenge your opinion.And so we begin...Read through the negative reviews and you'll begin to see a pattern emerge. A depressing, banal pattern. A group of people so deeply ingrained into their own cosy society they fail to see the forest for the trees.TrackMania Turbo does not let you customise your avatar. Shocker! Nor does it let you customise your car, your name, your horn or your server. I mean, strictly speaking, it does let you customise three of those things, but not in the same way its predecessor, TrackMania 2 did. You'll unlock new skins and stickers as you progress through the game, and hosting a multiplayer session supplies you with more or less all of the options you'd reasonably expect from a game of this type. Happy times, right?But wait. This isn't good enough for the snivelling elite. "Why can't I choose my OWN avatar?" they cry. "What if I want to assault players' ears with some Katy Perry while they drive?", "Why am I unable to smear their screens with ugly and pointless UI elements, just so I can enjoy a modest sense of authority?". The previous TrackMania game was undoubtedly far more open in terms of customisation. The reality is, however, that most of it was trash. I'm sorry, but custom horns and car skins are NOT that exciting and the majority of private servers looked as though someone had just eaten a phone book and promptly thrown up over the screen. Enough of that bullcrap about consoles dumbing down PC games, TrackMania was in desperate need of a clean up. And that's precisely what Nadeo have done. They've scraped off the scum and revealed a sparkling core underneath. Let me describe said core.Put simply, TrackMania can be described as a hotlap racer. The aim of the game is not to outwit your opponents in a head-to-head battle, but to master the track. This goal is enforced by the fact you're not actually able to collide with other cars at all. In both single player and online, other racers are essentially ghosts, forming vague representations of your opponents and their efforts to set low lap times. To put it simply, your biggest enemy is yourself. You'll repeat tracks over and over in quick succession, tapping the reset/restart buttons whenever the slightest mistake is made and slowly but surely, edging your way ever closer to perfection. Once you complete a lap (or several, in multilap events) your time will be awarded and your position displayed; bronze, silver or gold in single player and your rank versus other players in online matches. Then you'll hit the restart button for the thousandth time, because you know you can do better.In many racing games, this style of play could rightfully be considered dull, but not here. You've probably noticed via the promotional material that TrackMania tracks are out of this world cer-ay-zay. Drifting? Check. Blistering high speeds? You got it. Twists, loops, ramps, quarter pipes, magnetic tracks, jumps, wall rides and nail-biting close calls with brick walls? Par for the course, my friend! This is the true essence of TrackMania. The beating heart. The reason you came. And the same can be said for all TrackMania games. They're fantastic. The single thread that runs through the series, the one unifying theme that ties the franchise together... is the track design and the ability to create your own tracks. That hasn't gone anywhere. It's present in TrackMania Turbo and quite possibly better than ever. On the subject of unity, another point of contention seems to be the apparent separation of the player base. This is probably going to come across as patronising, but... yeah, that's kind of the nature of sequels. The general idea is that most players switch over, new players join and only a few stragglers are left behind. If you really want to whine about separation, direct it at the previous game. You know, the one that split each environment into individual releases. The truth is that TrackMania Turbo has done more to fix the separation issue than it has to worsen it. The more people move forward and pick it up, the more unified the community will be.Now, I'm not saying this is a flawless game. I have a modest, slowly growing list of issues I'd like to see addressed with a patch, but I had a list for the previous game too. A fairly sizeable list, if I'm honest. However, stepping back, taking a look at what really matters and focusing your attention on those central suppliers of enjoyment is all it takes to prove that ALL TrackMania titles are games worth playing. TrackMania Turbo being no exception.

												A lot of people have the wrong idea about Trackmania Turbo. They are seeing it as a sequel to Trackmania 2 (also known as ManiaPlanet). The fact of the matter is that TMT is infact, NOT a sequel. It is merely a spin off for consoles, except that the developers brought it to PC so we wouldn't miss out too. If you approach TMT as a side project, and not a sequel to TM2, then it is a very fun, enjoyable experience. It has all the stuff that is required for fun times with friends and other players online. Up to 4 player splitscreen, Double Driver mode (where two people control one car), and, of course a single player mode and track editor. For those of you who are freaking out about the 'consolified' editor, calm down! The classic editor is still there, to access it, start making a new map, and then you just need to move your mouse up to the top of the screen (so the menu bar shows), and click on the cog/gear, and choose the classic editor :)For video makers, the video editor is still there, too. It's accessed the same way (via the menu bar's cog/gear) on any of the main menus. Physics-wise, Nadeo seem to have tweaked the handling of existing environments (Canyon, Stadium, and Valley). None of the tweaking has rendered the environments bad to play, and they still retain their exclusively different handling styles. I can't give a complete coverage of optimization, as my system is fairly powerful. However, I have not had any performance issues at all, and no crashing either. However, it's running the exact same engine as Trackmania 2, so if you can run that, then you probably won't have any troubles running this!Sadly, you cannot paint your car in a detailed way in this game (like in Trackmania 2). This, again, is because it is a spin off side game for consoles, that was also released on PC to keep us happy. I won't complain - they could have not released the game at all for PC. All in all, this is a very solid fun game, and is worth picking up if you like fast-paced, skill based racing. Final rating: 8/10 (two points lost for track complexity limit, this could have easily been disabled for PC!).

												This is a pretty hard review to make, because Trackmania Turbo really isn't a bad game at all. Nadeo did a great job at optimizing it, with even my potato managing a smooth 60 frames at lowest settings. The game still looks great, even with the options cranked down. It is nice to see that they made sure it would run on lower end computers. The aesthetic, while goofy at times, is still pleasing and definitely is welcome change up. They even managed to mostly hit the addictive nature of the series, with the "just a little faster" mentality really showing through. Unfortunately though, the game bleeds compromise. I don't want to be the type of person to say that devs should make their games exactly like the previous installments. Fans can really stop Devs from trying something new or creating a creative game from an existing title. Series that produce new games with only some new levels and a fresh coat of paint are walking a fine line. Racing games are hard to make creative sequels for though. There is only so much one can change in a racing game without compromising what makes the racing game unique. Nadeo did a good job with Trackmania 2, changing up the pace a bit with a rally mode, among other things. Turbo though, appears to completely changed up some core concepts of Trackmania to an unwelcoming degree. Alot of the fun came from Trackmania's extremely unique take on racing. The cars where responsive to an unrealistic degree, and gripped the track like a magnet. The challenge, especially in later levels, would be maintaining speed in an increasing chaotic and cramped track. You had all the tools though to floor it, the question was did you have the skill. It was an idealized version of racing, where cars never skidded out, and one could restart at the push of a button. Wanted to go 600 kmh on a completely vertical curved portion of a wall? Why not? I have yet to play a game that approaches driving exactly the way Trackmania does. Turbo appears to have gone the route of its contemporaries though, and features a more realistic idea of driving. The cars have weight, and will do more normal car things. In doing this, they have made the game feel less precise. It is not to the level of weight of Need for Speed or Burnout have, but appears to be a mix of these games and classic Trackmania. It feels more precise than alot of it's rivals, but, unfortunately, is kinda easy like them as well, and has mechanics that could have been approached in a more Trackmania way. For example; I don't mind added blatant drifting to the game, but here it is incredibly simple. I expect a technique that allows one to cut off such large amounts of time to be a challenge to pull off, but it isn't at all. In the previous games drifting was difficult to control, and would only save time if one really understood how it worked. Here it seems to be thrown in because it is expected, or because it looks cool, not really to be an advanced technique to help one on the quest for the shinnies. This kinda sums up the game though. It is simply a gentrification of an already established series. Past installments have been completely community run. Nadeo lays out the frame work, and the community goes nuts. Here though, with the addition to a console port, Ubisoft has appeared to have forced Nadeo to turn it into every other game, with mechanics vaguely reminiscent of past titles, but mostly missing the mark. The car customization is laughable, and really doesn't feel like you are being creative in the slightest. The lack of community servers is sad, and even pc ports of other console games often have this. It has lost the community driven attitude of the past games, with only the track editor really remaining. Every decision has appeared to make the game more generic, to entice more people to try out the series. Only when one stops to sit though does one wonder why it was done in the first place. Why is there a random track option? It is a neat concept, but the tracks end up feeling imprecise and not very satisfying. Couldn't this time and money have been spent on something better. Apparently noEvery new feature or mechanic seems like a ploy by Ubisolf to entice more fans, but all seem to really lack depth. Am I going to spend more than five minutes with a friend on the two controllers one car mode? Probably not. I would rather race them one on one instead. It is amazing how long the last games have lasted with only a (admittingly amazing) track editor and community servers options. Here though, not only have they added a bunch of gimmicky features, but also made the game feel less skill based and more generic. It isn't a bad game. There is nothing wrong with pretty racing games that make you feel like you are going a million miles an hour and that have drifting that make you feel like Ken Block. But to not only lower the skill ceiling of one of the hardest racing games out there, but to also completely change its focus from community driven to something else is sad. I suppose it was inevitable, with Ubisoft being the publisher and whatnot, but it is still a disappointment to see.This is all coming from the perspective of a fan though. To those who haven't played or haven't enjoyed past Trackmania games, you should defiantly give it a go. It has fast racing, a great sense of speed, an addictive time trail mode, and gorgous visuals. To those expecting a new Trackmania game though, look elsewhere.

												I've been a longtime Trackmania fan, and this is the most fun I've had in a Trackmania game.Trackmania Turbo is a skill-based hotlap racing game where you play in one of four unique environments on an infinite variety of player-made (or randomly generated) tracks. It's fast, it's difficult, it's technical, and it's crazy fun.Pros:-New environment (Lagoon Rollercoaster) feels like a remake of the Snow environment from TMUF, and it looks amazing-Completely updated UI (It looks fantastic now. There are no 'janky' looking default font text labels popping up on the screen.-Cool new art direction (All of the signage, scenery objects that are present in all environments)-Unified gameplay experience (No need to close the game and open another just to play a different environment)-Double Driver is a really fun new multiplayer mode-New parts and smoother gameplay for existing environments-Huge singleplayer campaignCons:-From what I can tell, you can't save or edit your replays at this point. I hope this is either a planned or accidentally hidden feature.-Less customization than previous Trackmania games (for example, no custom car models)**This might not really be a bad thing. I personally prefer the more coherent art style that this forces.-You can't reassign controller inputs. The default layout is okay, but I'd prefer using the right analog stick for acceleration and brake (the default layout maps it to nothing at all).Should you buy it?-It's not an essential purchase if you are already invested in TM2, or if you prefer the deep customization of TM2.If you're looking to get into Trackmania, or if you want a more unified experience, this game is worth getting. Despite the bad reviews, this game is highly appealing and very fun in my opinion, and I think you'll have fun with it too. Best "6 out of 10 -Steam" I've ever played.

The environments seem fun even though it's basically just the previous 3 environments plus a new one, but the COMPLETELY console focused gameplay ruins it, especially when playing the Rollercoaster Lagoon environment with keyboard instead of a controller. The number one community feature just gets dropped for some lame-♥♥♥ wannabe server system, allowing for no customization at all, no jukebox, no plugins, no dedimania to compare your times against the world and the server itself. What is Trackmania without record-hunting? 												TL:DR: In any case, the game is highly recommended. The gameplay remained the same and has even been improved in some aspects, while some restrictions have been applied that ultimately don't make the game less fun, no matter how much the community may want to tell you otherwise. The new of the four enviroments, Lagoon, is awesome. Simply said, it is a streamlined trackmania game that kept all the fun parts and threw out the unnecessary ones - like lean meat that is still delicious. Don't listen to the others, buy it if you are interested in Trackmania.Long version:I must say, I am very disappointed. No, not in the game - in the reviews.I should first say that I have been playing trackmania for a long time - since around 2008, both online and offline, on LAN's and even one tournament.There are a lot of "supposedly" Trackmania-Veterans giving reviews here, thumbing the game down. They say that it sucks that the game has a lot less costumization compared to the other Trackmania games. They say it sucks that there are no dedicated servers. They say it sucks that the limit is now 100 players per server. They say that because of all of those reasons, it is a bad game. None of those reasons, none of those reviews, talk about the game itself. Why? It is great. And that the customization is gone is so bad?I say, ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. This was never what made Trackmania a great game. Sure, it was neat to customize your name and car in great detail, import new models, honks and even SFX, track graphics - all of that is gone now. And it has a reason it is gone - this is not supposed to be a successor to the old Trackmania games. It is it's own game, simply because it got a console release at the same time - it isn't connected to Maniaplanet, so that means a new community will form that is supposed to span consoles too.Yes, it sucks that a lot of community features are gone, but what does it matter? What makes Trackmania great - always has and always will - is the GAMEPLAY. And the gameplay is top notch. Racing online or offline is fun, fast, fluid and feels even more improved than it already has in the previous trackmania games. The trackbuilder is as varied and versatile as ever, allowing you to make some great creations and upload them for everyone to play. 4 Enviroments are there - Canyon, Valley, Lagoon and Stadium, all with different properties that require you to learn them and, even more than that, learn how your car behaves. The game is - simply - fun. Online play, even without dedicated servers, is still great - especially if you go to a server that plays random maps (the random trackbuilder isn't that great most of the time but it does provide some laughs and - most importantly - a somewhat even playing field. Still, Trackmania is and always has been about skill no matter what.) All of these negative reviews drive people away from what would otherwise be a great game - just because of Uplay and because the customization is largely gone? (You can still choose how your car looks and the choices aren't even that bad - the more gold medals you unlock, the more choices you have.)And this is what is funny to me. For years now Trackmania-Veterans have complained about the lack of players. They wanted a game that could bring new people into the trackmania series and provide them with an entry point, considering that most of the other Trackmania games have been seperately sold based on enviroment, aside from United (Trackmania Valley, Trackmania Canyon...). THIS GAME IS AN ENTRY POINT. And what do they reply? "Oh no, it is too dumbed down, so much stuff is missing bla bla bla" Stuff that only matters to someone who DOES NOT KNOW WHAT TRACKMANIA IS ABOUT. In the process, they drive players away. And then they start complaining again, about how Trackmania doesn't have enough players.This is a great game. Buy it. If you are new to Trackmania, you will love it and I urge you to also try the older games. If you are a veteran, buy it anyway. A lot of the customization is gone and the game as a whole feels more streamlined - but THAT IS OKAY. It is not supposed to be a successor to the PC-trackmanias. It is it's own game. And what made trackmania great, the gameplay, the fast and fluid racing, the surprising courses by the community - all that is there and it looks better than ever. All that has changed is that you can't assault people with customized "Let the bodies hit the floor" Honks or race around with your ♥♥♥♥ing Hatsune-Miku painted car. If this is all that ever mattered to the community, then well - maybe this community isn't as welcoming as they would always want to be. But this is it's own game, it's own community. It is up to you to shape it to become less elitist than the old one.It does everything it needs to well. The only negative point I can see is Uplay and even so - Uplay isn't as bad as a lot of people may want you to believe, though I do agree it is useless in this context, considering this game is sold on Steam. And while I do not absolutely love Uplay - let's be honest, it is okay. Just okay though.

Introduction:I've played basically every Trackmania game prior to the Trackmania 2 - series coming out, and thought it might be a good Idea to pick up a copy of this game primarily due to the fact that it's not 30 bucks for a single environment. I was looking for it to fill the void that the older titles left a couple of years back.So I got it and played through the "White Series"-tracks to test the general feel of each car/environment, took a quick look at the editor and customization, played a bit of multiplayer and went on to write this review/impression.The tl;dr conclusion is that, yes, I like it and I would recommend it. Since there's a whole bunch of negative reviews, though, I feel like mentioning their arguments and adding my own opinion to them.A couple of criticisms I would like to adress beforehand: This will require uPlay to play. No way around. The game will default to controller prompts. It will also make your controller vibrate if plugged in and playing with keyboard. I don't know where people got the idea of this having no audio options at all: hover over the top area of your screen, you will find a black bar containing audio sliders for master volume, music and sound volume. It's probably not the most expansive audio menu, but I think it does all it needs to do. No dedicated servers: I suppose since this is a console port, PC was not the target demographic and therefore got left behind in that regard. It's a shame really, but I wasn't into TM for the community's sake in the first place. It don't bother me all that much. Gameplay:The cars do feel different to the ones in prior Trackmania titles, and while it took some getting used to I don't think they're better or worse than before. They feel like they have a lot of weight behind them which makes them seem a lot more realistic and it feels as if every little mistake is punished even harder this time around. The basic gameplay loop hasn't changed, you try a course, fail, and try again until you have basically mastered every turn, every jump, every drift and so on. Cars having no collision in multiplayer adds to this "Trial & Error" type of gameplay, in which you always compete for the best time.I've heard people complain about handling, but I've had no issues with it so far. The game never made me feel like I failed for any reason other than me legitimately ♥♥♥♥ing up. Feels true to the Trackmania spirit for me.Graphics:The graphics have been severely upgraded from back in the days. What I remember being, compared to this, rather cutesy and comic-ish in older games now looks really solid and realistic. The 4 different environments do a lot to differentiate themselves from each other as well as previous environments, while still integrating some familiar elements here and there. I wouldn't go so far as to call the graphics amazing in and of themselves, but I think the tracks can look breathtakingly cool and overall, you'll still have to admit the graphics look pretty decent.Environments:Since the International Stadium is basically a carbon copy of Trackmania Nations' Stadium environment and Canyon Grand Drift and Valley Down & Dirty  are strongly reminiscent of the original Trackmania's Desert and Rally environments, I'm not going to go into a lot of depth on those.Rollercoaster Lagoon, my personal favourite, however feels like a completely original environment. I'm surprised I haven't seen more games go down this route, as the rollercoaster courses take an awesome basic concept and make it their own. Those tracks combine the rather chill atmosphere of Trackmania Sunrise's levels and add a whole other set of giant magnetic rollercoaster parts to it that make you feel like you're actually controlling one, as ridiculous as that sounds.The amount of different pieces you can use to design your track make every one of them feel diverse and original.Customization:Yes, the old style of customizing every little detail of your car's paintjob and your avatar is gone. Does it make the game worse, though? Now, I don't think so, but I've never been too much into the customization aspect. Back when I played the first Trackmania, I would take about 10 to 20 minutes each to customize my cars. When I went back to play it or any of the following games, I would pick a premade paintjob and be happy with it and the additional 30 minutes I got out of that. There seems to be a good number of premade paintjobs which are unlocked through beating the in-game challenges, and I probably won't ever see the entirety of them, so I'm satisfied in that regard.Editor:All those screaming and raging about the old editor: it's still there. This game was a console-port iirc, so it makes sense to fine tune the editor to fit a console's input methods and preferably use this method of editing tracks. If you don't like that, you can switch to the old editor by using the "Settings" Icon on the in-game taskbar at the top. My only nitpick is that using the old editor apparently converts the map to be edited in that mode only, if that was a deliberate design decision, I don't see the point. It only takes a second or so to convert the maps though, so I don't really have a problem with it.I don't think I really need to say anything about the old editor, it gave you heaps of freedom and made it really easy to design tracks. I'm probably not going to use the console editor, I don't see why anyone on pc would.Multiplayer:While I haven't tried out a lot of multiplayer, and there's been complaints about missing dedicated servers, I decided to quickly hop on a random custom game and see if there were any major issues with the netcode or multiplayer implementation on pc. I didn't experience any. It's the same kind of time attack multiplayer that was present in previous games, so I hazard to guess that it's going to be alright. I can not say for sure if the hardcore-online community that made the original game a success is still going to be pleased by it. In conclusion, it still feels like Trackmania for me, and I will probably keep enjoying it for multiple hours being content with the amount of money I spent (29,99€ on sale). There's little things like the attention to detail (i.e. you can see the suspension work on slopes) that make it seem to me like this game was actually created with the purpose of making another solid entry to the series, and I think they managed.Would recommend to anyone that liked the previous/older titles just on the merit of getting another fix.

												There’s a terrible bias in many of the reviews posted so far. I felt inclined to post my own review to cater to people who may not have a problem with Uplay or Ubisoft. This is largely because real downsides in the game’s design are being completely ignored. Uplay has very rarely caused me problems. Some of the more recent updates to Uplay have made it less “intrusive.” If you already have a Uplay account and other newer Ubisoft games, then there’s absolutely nothing to worry about when it comes to Uplay.Should you buy this game if you are a long time player of Trackmania games? That’s exactly what I did. I’ve been playing different versions of Trackmania for years. My experience with the game is probably different from many PC gamers. I played this game primarily in a couch co-op/party play type of setting with friends. Single player and internet play was something I barely touched during the years that I’ve played previous Trackmania titles. Playing with friends in the same room meant playing hot seat. I’ve played countless hours of incredibly entertaining Trackmania hot seat over the years. My Trackmania gaming experience was based on speed, precision (taking inches off corners) and friendly but aggressive competition. I’ve never not had a version of this game installed somewhere. Does Trackmania Turbo deliver that same experience? Yes. Does it add to that experience? Yes. We now have track and vehicle types that change the way you need to drive because of the handling and terrain combination. This is great because it adds a certain kind of “variety” to the racing. We also have split screen and different multiplayer modes. The new multiplayer modes are where I think the execution was faulty. Modes like “mono screen” are hidden until you provide button codes to activate them. What you can immediately infer is that you’re left to understanding the modes yourself. How do I perform stunts or battle my friends? How do I mix modes up? None of this is immediately obvious. Getting the full hot seat playability out of the game is, unfortunately, a challenge. I fail to see why the game was designed this way. Wouldn't it have been wiser to fully open the local multiplayer modes of the game and provide enough information for us to immediately jump into playing?I can't comment on the difference between the single player and online experience between this game and past games but I can say that the single player is fun and challenging; it is exactly what I expected from Trackmania and more.

												NOTE: NADEO HAS SAID THEY WILL BE BRINGING THE NEW ENVIRONMENT, LAGOON, TO TRACKMANIA 2.BUYER BEWARE: This is a game that, although will feel very familar to Trackmania fans, will not be all that welcoming to them. Buy with the knowledge that this is TM2's Canyon, Valley, and Stadium with one new environment/playstyle, but is ultimately lacking in moddable freedom. Although I give it a "Not Recommended," I solely mean that speaking as a TM for veteran TM players. It is not a bad title, and if the lack of modding/dedicated servers doesn't bother you, please pick this up.Let me get this out of the way. Do not be fooled, Trackmania Turbo is a fantastic title. The core gameplay has been refined and tuned significantly. The sense of speed is superb, the driving feels so much better, and the graphics are really beautiful. But, where it shines in a lot of areas, it fails everywhere else.If you're at all familiar to the previous generations of Trackmania then you'll know the following: Trackmania is a content sharing game. Trackmania has always been about dedicated servers where people can upload music tracks, plugins, add custom made community levels, and had a huge modding community primarily for custom car models and skin designs. Trackmania allowed people to have their own unique personality online. There was even an in-game paint editor if you weren't savvy enough to understand editing skins in Photoshop.TRACKMANIA TURBO DOESN'T FEATURE ANY OF THIS ASIDE FROM THE TRACK EDITOR. AND THE TRACK EDITOR DOESN'T WORK WITHOUT A CONTROLLER.And, to be fair, I don't want to say Nadeo doesn't care. This game was pretty much their big introduction to the console scene as their last attempt with the Wii game didn't go so well. When it comes to consoles dedicated servers are never a thing due to Sony/Xbox having gripes about that sorta thing. It should go without saying too that content-sharing custom content wouldn't be possible on the console without making an entire in-game editor as complex as Forza or APB. As a way to still keep the customization a thing, there are a ton of liveries, sponsor emblems, numbers, flags, and metal trimmings you can unlock to customize your stock car. It would appear Nadeo didn't want to completely alienate PC players from a newer installment, but subsquently didn't want to make one version be the "superior" version. This is further backed up by Nadeo saying they are going to add Turbo's newest environemnt, Lagoon, into TM2. The community admin for this forum has also claimed that Turbo should not be treated as TM3 as they are completely different expierences.I can't say much about the new game modes but, as it stands, this is not meant for die hard trackmania fans. Yes, custom tracks can still be shared and played. Yes, the gameplay is incredibly refined from TM2 and is, in my opinion, much more fun to play. The only issue is that the content PC players are used to isn't there, and it makes sense why it isn't. It doesn't necessarily mean it's a bad game though. If you're looking for a more streamlined experience where you're less likely to play horrible maps with a community that is much more active than TM2 is right now then do pick this up. It's still a great game... even if it is just Valley/Canyon/Stadium packaged together with a new environement.

												These are the TrackMania environments included in this package...Canyon Grand Drift:-This is the Turbo variant on the Canyon environment from TrackMania 2.-This environment has a heavy emphasis on high-speed drifting.-Offroading generally occurs on flat surfaces, unless you are racing in underground tunnels. It is quite slide-y, which will likely throw new players off. But I found it to be pretty easy to get used to.-Usage of air control is very infrequent.-Driving on loops is incredibly difficult, as the car tends to loose traction when wallriding.-Excellent sense of scale. Big things feel very big, and small things feel small.Down 'n' Dirty Valley:-This is the Turbo variant on the Valley environment from TrackMania 2.-This environment has a heavy emphasis on offroading, understanding where to enter and exit turns, and air control.-Offroading is very difficult and will take some time to learn. I've found that the subtle inputs possible with analog steering are very helpful. Grassy areas seem to slow your car down.-Air control is vital for landing jumps properly, as well as keeping yourself from flying off the track when slopes are a bit too convex.-Wallriding and looping tend to be hit-and-miss in this environment. I can't say that I've nailed down any definitive technique quite yet, but I will tweak this review if I do.-The valley setting is gorgeous and serene.Rollercoaster Lagoon:-This is the Turbo variant on the Lagoon environment, which will be released for TrackMania 2 at some point in the future.-The LagoonCar's turn radius is easily the smallest of all the Turbo environments. It is so small that players will rarely find themselves utilizing braking, drifting, or even lifting off to make it through turns. Thus, the emphasis of Lagoon is primarily on the search for the optimal race line in itself. The challenge here comes from being able to maintain your momentum through slippery sand/grass and slick roads, as well as finding the optimal race line on the brain-melting magnetic rollercoaster track segments that do an excellent job of utilizing 3D space to create very intricate tracks. It also has water bouncing, which is just so great.-This environment, in my experience, has the most difficult offroading. You will mostly find yourself racing on sand, which is very slippery. And your situation certainly isn't helped by the fact that the sloping on the sandy track segments tends to be very convex, and the transitions to and from offroading tend to be very awkward. Grassy segments seem to slow you down. The slick roads take some getting used to, and transitioning to and from them can be awkward.-I haven't found flying off the track to be a big problem when it comes to slopes, even on sand. It just feels awkward. Even so, air control is useful for making your landing after a jump a bit more smooth.-Lagoon is an aquired taste, and said taste is more easily aquired if you've played classic TrackMania. But it is a lot of fun once you start to get good. It is easily the prettiest of the environments. It has the second sexiest car in the game, just behind the one for Stadium. The car feels incredibly heavy, so maintaining your momentum through turns, rollercoaster segments, slick segments, and offroad segments is incredibly satisfying. This environment easily does the best job of all the TrackMania environments to date of utilizing 3D space to make super intricate tracks.International Stadium:-This is the Turbo variant on the Stadium environment from TrackMania Nations Forever, TrackMania United, and TrackMania 2.-This environment doesn't really have a huge emphasis on one particular gameplay mechanic. It just kinda does a little bit of everything. But it does it well. Also, there is water bouncing. Awesome.-This environment has the easiest offroading. While there is definitely less traction than when you drive on asphalt, it is not nearly as chaotic as the other environments. Grass seems to slow you down, but I haven't played many tracks that require you to drive on grass.-This is the environment in which air control is the most heavily utilized. The biggest reason for this is that the Stadium physics aren't nearly as forgiving as the other environments when it comes to landing jumps. You have to use air control to keep your car level with wherever you are going to land so you don't end up losing speed or crashing.-This environment is probably the best of the Turbo environments. It takes the already well-refined formula of Stadium and refines it more, adding more interesting visuals in the process. Also, it has the sexiest Nadeo-made car I've seen to date.Here are some pros and cons...Pros:-Unlike TrackMania 2, Turbo is multiple environments in a single package.-User interface is much prettier and more accessible than previous TrackMania games.-I personally think the way the campaign menus are laid out is really nice.-Horn customization has been excluded. Many people would put this in their cons, but I personally prefer not to have my speakers and headphones assaulted with annoying jingles and ear-♥♥♥♥♥♥ music.-Turbo is easily the prettiest installment in the TrackMania series thus far. Plus, the car models are incredibly sexy and very fitting for TrackMania.-It seems to perform better than TrackMania 2.-Heli-drops as starting lines.-Unlike previous TrackMania games, Turbo does an excellent job of making the cars feel heavy without negatively impacting their handling. It feels less like you are playing with toy cars and more like you are cruising around in full-sized souped-up racing vehicles. It makes carrying your momentum through turns all the more satisfying.-The dynamic music provides an excellent means of feedback and atmosphere.-I found the random track generator to actually be a lot of fun. Because of the random nature of the tracks, you will find that completing many randomized tracks requires the utilization of a lot of unconventional driving skills, such as braking over turbo pads or slowing down at just the right time and place before a jump so you don't overshoot or undershoot the landing. Thus, I'd actually recommend messing around with the random generator if you want to improve your skills in certain environments.-Soundtrack customization.Neutral:-Unlike this game's motto, I would argue that TrackMania is not universally easy to pick up, regardless of the simplicity of its controls. But it is definitely hard to master.-TrackMania Turbo is a spinoff rather than a sequel, so don't worry about this being the new primary formula for TrackMania games to come.-Includes the new Double Driver mode, wherein the vehicle accepts inputs from two players simultaneously.Cons:-Turbo requires Uplay to play. If you purchase it through Steam, it will require Uplay AND Steam to play.-This game has four environments and is more expensive than TrackMania United, which has seven environments and is worth 75% the price of Turbo.-Modding has been removed entirely. The only user-created content in this game comes from a simplistic (but admittedly kinda fun) car painter and a watered-down track builder.-Like all TrackMania games, it can be incredibly frustrating.-The online multiplayer community isn't very active. Like... at all.-Like I said earlier, the track builder has been grotesquely watered down. I'm pretty sure mix mapping is impossible. 												Believe it or not, I'm not giving Turbo a negative review because HURR DURR MUH CUSTOM MODELS AND HORNSIt's nice to have a Trackmania game that has all of it's enviornments in one game, a Trackmania game that's not plagued with crap surrounding the screen in multiplayer...a Trackmania game that's purely about getting to the finish line in the fastest time. Turbo knows what it is, and it handles it's purpose as a time trial game exceedingly well. However, Trackmania Turbo DOES have enough flaws that makes it hard to recommend to veterans of the series.The biggest thing is the way the cars handle. The enviornment that feels the best is probably Canyon; the cars in Canyon feel a bit heavier than in TM2 but they still retain their fun drift physics. That part of the game feels great. It's just a little less responsive, unfortunately. Likewise, the Stadium cars feel heavier and less responsive as well, and considering how popular Stadium is I think they should have left it alone. In stark contrast, the Lagoon cars are twitchy as all hell and you can complete all of the White tracks without even touching the brakes once. The twitchiness would be ok, but the controller deadzone is incredibly small and there's no obvious way to change it. If you're trying to play Lagoon on keyboard, God help you. The worst of the bunch is Valley. Valley was unpopular in TM2, and it's still just as bad. Those cars have a stupidly wide turning radius until you gently tap the brakes, and then they suddenly have incredibly massive oversteer. And that's just on pavement; Valley cars control like pure crap on dirt, and there's a lot of dirt in Valley.This wouldn't be nearly as bad if you could tackle one enviornment at a time, but you cant. First you do the 10 White tracks in Canyon, which unlocks the first 10 White tracks in Valley, and so on. Doing tracks in one enviornment should unlock more tracks in the same enviornment; that way, the player has time to really hone their skills in one before moving on to another. In Turbo, as soon as you get used to one enviornment, you have to move to another. It's not done very well.Furthermore, this is a REALLY lazy port. I know this is mainly a console game that's also seeing a PC release, but this is really sad coming from a developer that created originally Trackmania as a PC exclusive series. The options that you can change are almost as limited as Dark Souls. Visually, the game's pretty attractive, but I wish there was more that I could control.Tl;dr, if you're a Trackmania veteran you're probably not going to like the changes that have been made to the existing enviornments. If you're a new player, you'll probably ge able to get used to it fairly quickly. Hopefully Nadeo turns their attention back to TM2 quickly, because I think I'm gonna pass on Turbo.

												Trackmania has had a bit of a troubled past. Their first major hit 'Trackmania Nations' was free to play, and played by hundreds of thousands of people simultaneously worldwide. A combination of Trackmania 2 being divided by gameplay type (canyon, valley, stadium) and the games no longer being free to play started to harm the games reputation - the playerbase was dwindling, as fans were so divided amongst several versions of the game, they all appeared to be dead. Trackmania Turbo aims to fix that.First and foremost, this game has uPlay and requires a separate account. You can't escape this, even the console version asks you to register and use an account separate from your PSN/XBL ID. It's not really worth complaining about in this context as equal effort is required no matter your platform of choice.As far as PC options go, it's barebones and actually quite bad in a few instances. True fullscreen mode is hit or miss; enabling it on my PC shows the interface at the correct aspect ratio, but 3d elements of the game are rendered in 4:3 then stretched to 16:9, which looks awful, as are the the uplay and steam overlays. Getting a proper 16:9 ratio required that I played the game in borderless window mode. There are no options to change your controller bindings, and detection of xinput pads can be spotty, too - my Xbox 360 controller is detected by the game, but actually operates in Dinput mode, which means only the right or left trigger can be active at any given time. They are detected as the same axis. For drifting and braking, this requires me to rely on tapping 'A' to initiate a drift, and I must fully release the right trigger to brake at all. Graphics options are equally barebone, and setting the water to 'highest' actually causes graphical defects.However, these are elements that can be worked around - using a different controller (such as a DS4 or Xbox One controller) properly detects and uses Xinput functionality, allowing you to hold the right trigger to accelerate and tap the left trigger to initiate a drift just like you can on the consoles. Once you're logged into uPlay, you can set it to remember your credentials and you'll never have to think about it again. Playing in borderless window mode is indistinguishable from fullscreen mode and as an added bonus, eliminates screen tearing without having to enable vsync, plus you can alt tab quickly from the game. Graphically speaking, the game is on par with the console versions even at the medium settings, and seems to be optimized well - my modest rig can easily run the game at 60+fps. Patches are reportedly on the way to fix issues with controllers.I won't get too in-depth on how this game compares to previous titles, because frankly, as Nations went on, the dedicated servers and level of customization available to players converted the interface into a huge mess, and the maps you could race on became less fun to a casual player over time, as the diehard fans demanded more difficult, puzzle-like maps to play on.What you get here is a 200 map-strong campaign, spread across 4 unique playstyles. Each car handles very differently, and for the first time in the series, each mode is truly united - the interface seamlessly transitions you from environment to environment, because they are all actually part of a single game, an improvement over previous entries in the series. You can join a server that runs maps from multiple environments, also a first for the series. The game is very fast paced and has many arcade qualities to it. One perk of playing on PC is dramatically improved loading times - my time on the beta and later on, the demo for the PS4, had me waiting upwards of 25 seconds to load into a new map. Installing this game to an SSD on my PC has reduced that time to a mere 7 seconds, and i'm operating on a lower end SSD, too. The controls are responsive, and there's no stuttering or wait times to restart the entire map or from your previous checkpoint. There are per-map and overall rankings divided into multiple sections, allowing you to see how you measure up to the world, your country, and even down to the state level. Aiming for gold is just the beginning - the game makes it very clear to you how you measure up, and the small nature of each track encourages you to keep trying until you achieve trackmaster (a hidden ranking beyond gold) or become one of the best players in your region.Taking the game online allows you to filter servers down to something you can enjoy, and you race against real-time ghosts of up to 99 others on the server. It feels good to know exactly how you stack up against others not only on a world/country/state level, but how you fare against others in a more intimate, competitive environment that demands consistently good performance out of you. It's nice to be able to witness how others take on the course, too. A current problem lies in how the servers are handled, though - since they're hosted by the developers, there's currently no easy way for you to make a track and share it with others. Reportedly, they're working on a fix for this, but in the mean time, you still have 200 official maps to occupy yourself with.I personally believe the game is very fun, and lives up to the Trackmania name. This game represents the best opportunity for the entire community to come together and settle on a single game. Many of the complaints you'll see in the other reviews are valid, but overblown. The worst problems very quickly move out of your way and aren't really a issue anymore, beyond the games initial setup.

												This is probably the best arcade PC racing game right now. DEFINITELY buy it over TrackMania 2. It may be a bit more console-ified, but if anything it needed it. In TrackMania 2 there were stupid little "dedimania" things all over the screen in multiplayer, which were most useless. Dedimania had things like server records, donation links and more. While this may have been helpful to a hardcore player who came back to the server frequently, it only served as a huge distraction for anyone else just casually looking to jump into an online match. Also, this edition doesn't have you pay out money for each individual section of the game (a decision which has almost killed TrackMania to this day). For $40.00, TrackMania Turbo gives you: Four different environments each with a distinct vehicle to drive, tools to create an almost infinite amount of different tracks to race on, a large single player campaign with 50 challenges for each environment, online multiplayer with an abiet small but unified community, a car customizer inferface (with different decals and color options to choose) a replay editor. The menus, interface and level editors are also optimized for controller use (should you want to play on TV or not switch between mouse and controller.For $50, TrackMania 2 gives you: three environments each with the same vehicles to drive as their Turbo counterparts, (with different models), tools to create a nearly infinite amount of different tracks to race on, three medium single player campaigns, one for each environment (containing around 80 per environment), car painter with tools to create a completely unique look for the car you choose, tools to import other models for use as cars, controls not optimized for controller (they can be used, but the game doesn't seem to accept analog acceleration options), online multiplayer with very small, divided communities (good matches can be very difficult to find), and dedimania *cringe*.Do what you want with your money. I still find that TrackMania Turbo's improved controls, aesthetic, more expansive content and more active community produces a much more well made racing game.

Because from the video i had hope of having a new micro machine type of game... no it's not. One after the other to have the whole screen for ourselves.Something else now that i haven't been reading anywhere, is the gameplay itself.We now have 4 environnements to play with, each with different cars and roads and grips. They are fun to drive, and the small differences between them makes it interesting.But.To be honest, they all pretty much very similar and come to handling high speed. There is no more of that technique you could find in the first one, with the snow level for example or the mediterranean one; where the challenge wasn't so much the speed and fast tracks but more towards the specificity of how the car was behaving.And now i feel like all the different cars have come to the same thing: too much speed.Maybe it's what made the game famous and fun, but i think they should have put a slower one in the middle to have some variations in gameplay, and more challenges for gamers. See my picture profile ? I need glasses and i'm getting too old for such speed!Ah anyway, in summary:PROS:- Lot of content in Solo- Inifinite content thanks to editor- multiplayer looks stable- interface is simple and nice to use- nice to have split screen- funny and interesting two drivers seat- sound, atmosphere & graphicsCONS:- lack of variations in gameplay between cars. 												The graphics and three of the environments have already been established by previous TM games, so i won't touch on those. So i'll just dabble into a few things that put me off:First of all, the customization. TM is incredibly famous for the ability to choose out of hundreds of community-created models and skins for your vehicles, as well as giving you the reins to make your own. This game... not so much. While i think that the new cars for the older environments look really nice, there's little to their customization as all you're offered are rather basic patterns with different palettes unlocked by random goals: even the ability to pick your own colors for these patterns would've been much much better. The unlockable customizations don't really have anything to do with their unlocking demands, so a better idea would've been just to give them all right away and not make them some illusion of a reward for X gold medals.Second, music. The previous TM games offered 1-3 tracks per environment and i'm quite sure Sunrise was the only one to use licensed (if obscure, though fitting) music. This game has an entire licensed soundtrack, which is something else. Though i have never seen any of these names, not even the Monstercat ones i'd expect to recognize. And while i obviously can't speak for everyone when i say i don't like the music, i think i can rather objectively say that any of it doesn't fit the game at all. Absolutely none of the songs even remotely fit Trackmania as it is. Moreover, the music changes every single time you respawn, which if you've ever played a TM game you know that it will happen over and over again, making the music more annoying than the worst tracks. My advice, blacklist every song and play your own.But not so bad that there's nothing good. I enjoy the new take on things such as the scenery props and the HUD. The game feels a lot like a singleplayer game, like it'd have cutscenes or maybe even a plot. I think the idea of Trackmania as an established, international spectator sport comes through nicely. Sadly, the poorness of customization and trackbuilding (while i'm not a trackbuilder myself, i've yet to hear people actually like it), which are big cornerstones of TM as we know it, prevent me from recommending the game. Maybe if you've never played a TM game, this could be something to start off from, and if you like it you can perhaps branch to the actual TM games and expect a more down-to-earth approach, so to say. Then again, you could just try TM Nations instead which would save you 40 bucks whether you liked it or not. But as a longstanding fan of the TM series, Turbo feels almost like a sub-par spinoff. Though it is nice that console players get a taste of TM as well.

												Visuals: this game is art. Everything flashes and has this colorful arcade feel that fits the game's style perfectly. Technically, graphics quality is the same from Trackmania 2. But visuals are better because of a nicer artistic direction.Audio: There's more than 40 tracks by EDM producers in the game. If you like house you're gonna love this. During races, the music is dynamically mixed according to your speed. This makes you get pumped in high speed tracks, but isn't perfect, especially in tracks where you speed up and down constantly. Sound FX are vastly improved from the previous games, including turbo sounds, engine sounds, ambient and crashing sounds. There's also an announcer, which you may like or not, but you can turn off anyway.Gameplay: In comparison to previous Trackmania - The multiplayer game is no longer a spreadsheet simulator. "Hardcore fans" dislike it. I like it. Some unimportant customization is gone. The important, like replay editing, track building and custom games, are still here. Completely custom servers are going to be added in the next patch. But the racing, which is what actually is the core of Trackmania, remains the same from previous games. Amazing sense of speed, completely crazy tracks and great controls. Gameplay is based on time trials and shaving off precious centiseconds to get the best time. However, Trackmania isn't for you if you want a game with car-to-car collisions or simulation.Interface/Customization: Menus are stylish, but some settings are hidden in a bar that appears only when you hover your mouse on the top of the screen. And these settings are important. There's sliders for music/sound FX volume, graphics settings, a replay editor, the classic track editor and control configuration hidden there. A lot of people are missing this and giving the game bad ratings.Car painting has been simplified from the previous games. Instead of painting your own car, you unlock skins and pre-placed stickers for cars. It adds a sense of progression, but it would be nice if you could paint manually too. Maybe in an update?HUD could be better. Since it was made with consoles in mind the elements are bigger than they need to be and end up being distracting (especially in multiplayer). However, this should be the easiest thing to fix with a patch.I have been playing Trackmania since United. For me, this one is great, maybe even the best.

A good Trackmania experience for consoles, ported back to the PCTL;DRI'd not be recommending this at full price. If you're a first timer who wants to try out TM, get the older freewares and try them out to see if TM is your thing. TM Turbo is more of a reboot of the series for the next-gen console age (& PC), and it's a fun and good reboot at that. If you liked the freewares and don't own TM2, this won't disappoint you much.Full Review:A reasonably priced and equally good addition to the TM franchise. While it still plays like TM (acc,brake,left,right), the PC version isn't without it's issues. This game feels like it was made for consoles and to be fair, that's kind of true. It was a NinDS title years back and even the beta was only available for PS4/XBone. However, since the previous titles were exclusive to PCs, a full PC support is a given considering its history. If you're someone who's looking for that, this isn't that game. Here are some things that I disliked about this PC version- Settings (graphics,input) -> Move cursor up to the top of the screen and click the gear icon in the drop down bar. I'd have preferred them to be somewhere more visible, like in the settings menu. Graphics Issues -> If you turn up all water reflection to max possible and look at the water, there's black dots everywhere. Solution? Turn down water reflection to medium. (controller) ZeroVery little rumble on my F710 with XInput. Also, I coundn't find any controller layout screen. (controller) An issue where if want to drift with LT(brake)+Stick, it won't register the LT as brake if RT(acc) is also pressed down. Feature downgrade -> No private servers. All rooms hosted on dev servers. Feature downgrade -> Servers have max 100 players, far fewer than it should've been. Feature downgrade -> Customisation is restricted to paint jobs and decals. However, paintjobs/decals arent' car specific and are applied to every single car for all the environments. The playlist is nice but there's only a couple in there and after the first few tracks, it's repetitive. More variety or an in-built custom playlist support would've been nice. 3 of 4 environments are from the previous game though it looks beautiful here. (Lagoon will be added to TM2 as DLC) UPLAY BONUS -> If you're in a region, say, a country which you know is in the continent you've  been given the key for, you won't be able to activate it if Ubisoft thinks you aren't in the region. Tough luck; get a VPN and activate it anyway. I know it's UPlay but I didn't expect this.Nevertheless, the game is fun and a TM game at its core- Race tracks are pretty varied, starting with simple turns that get more challenging as you progress. Feels more driftier but I could be wrong. The environment is beautiful for a game where the sole focus is on cutting down every unnecessary millisecond off your lap time. And the map is open-world ish. If your eyes can see it, your drive can drive there. 


you could probably go anywhere you can see on the map

By: Bandicoot







....even underwater

 Carries over the track builder for countless hours of extra gameplay. Would've been nice if there was a Steam Workshop type feature for sharing user created tracks offline but I don't think that'll happen. Because you see, consoles don't do that, so PC can't. Runs at a near constant 60fps at 1080p with every setting maxed out on i7-4710HQ + 860M. No DLC or micro-transactions, at least none that I know of.Every positive point here isn't something new to TM and it isn't something that TM Turbo does better than it's predecessors. Yes it has got much better graphics and yes it now has a dynamic soundtrack. The game if anything, has been dumbed down. But I still like to play it and I have fun playing it. It's a good reboot, just not a good enough TM sequel.

												was really into it for the first couple of hours and then the cracks started to show.The developer did (mostly) a great job of tightening up all the weird Trackmania 2 stuff into a neat little package. It has a nice coat of paint on it and is quite cohesive (mostly).They revamped the cars to make them more hotrod like, there's an announcer dude reacting to whatever you do on the track, the existing environments have been spiced up with these weird neon signs, there's turbo flames coming out of your car when getting onto a boost. Everytime there's the 3 2 1 countdown before a race starts, it happens in a different language. The game has a killer intro movie. There's these weird cool quotes on the loading screens.The online custom track sharing is very bad. No straightforward way to find, download and play custom tracks in a game where the Trackbuilder is featured so prominently that it's on the very first line in the main menu. It isn't helped by the fact that you can't name any of your tracks. All the tracks you make follow the naming structure of "Username [Tracknumber] [Tracklength] [Trackstyle]", e.g. "Kewlsnake 17 Short Tech" would be a track I made. Oh and you can't delete any of the tracks that you upload online!The server names follow a similar naming structure as the tracknames and I think this combined with the very rudimentary custom track sharing will severely hamper the online community component in the long run.I think the singleplayer campaign is pretty great, it features 200 tracks from the 4 different environments (one new for this game, the others have been featured in other games). I think the unlocking of tracks could've been handled better. You need to get either bronze/silver or gold medals in 100% of the previous maps to unlock the next set of maps which is always a different environment. I would've liked to see that doing well in Stadium maps would unlock more Stadium maps for me or that if I did very well in previous maps and got either silver or gold medals instead of the required bronze, I would unlock certain sets of maps earlier. Now I'm forced to get medal X in 100% of previous maps to unlock the next set. I would've liked that getting medal X in most of the maps would've been enough to unlock the next map.The local coop component seems to be pretty fleshed out. You have Hotseat, Arcade, Split Screen, Mono Screen and a Double Driver campaign all for coop fun. There is also a "secret" mode where you can enter cheat codes which consists out of punching in 3 of the face buttons to get one of the local coop modes + a twist. Very cool in concept, in practice quite ♥♥♥♥♥♥ because the 64 possible different combinations only end up in the 4 local coop modes + a couple of very minor changes, giving out 9 different "modes" in total.There's a Stunts mode in the game that the game barely acknowledges. You can enable it on the online servers but zero explanation about it.You can save replays, the game never acknowledges how you can do this (you press R).There's this random track generator in the game which is cool. I don't think the tracks it makes are particularly great. I feel like you need to slowdown a lot or you'll crash into something in the air or the turns aren't properly signaled or there's a turbo just before this very tight turn. Stuff like that. Maybe good for tech tracks?I think the car customization stuff is ok. Not elaborate but you can unlock more stuff by getting more gold medals and it has a nice progression. You can also get upto 6 "Legendary Paintworks" by spending uplay points which is a total makeover for your car. I personally like the Double Driver one a lot.In general, I don't think I would recommend a purchase unless you're interested in the singleplayer campaign / local coop part. If you're interested in a vibrant online community, go buy Trackmania 2: Stadium for 5 bucks on Steam now or try out the demo or try out Trackmania Nations Forever which is free.The release of Turbo has revitalised TM2: Stadium again which is cool.I think it's pretty sad/funny that even in the new Turbo game, people keep playing Stadium, even in favor of the new environment (Rollercoaster Lagoon).EDIT: Some things that are cool about Turbo that aren't immediately noticeable.There is an "Use Joker" option after finishing a track that's greyed out initially. Say that you need to get a Silver Medal for a track to proceed but can't quite manage to hit that time. After you hit the bronze medal 3 times, you will get a "Silver Joker" which allows you to proceed to the next track.On top of that, there's some cool visual language going on in the campaign track selection screen.In the start, if you get the required bronze medals for the next tracks to unlock, they squares will get filled up. From the moment you need to score silver medals to unlock more tracks, only the squares where you have gotten silver medals are filled. So the game adjusts to what you're needing at that moment which is cool.Also, see the 23 that's coloured in green? That's a track where I've gotten the Trackmaster medal (Which is where I've beaten the time of the track author).See how the 55 track is half filled? That's because it's a track where I've obtained the Silver Joker that I talked about earlier. It counts as a Silver medal for all accounts and purposes but if I want to get a "legit" silver medal, I can always go back to that track and get it.Pretty cool!

												I have played every Trackmania game to date. This is primarily going to compare them, but also think of Turbo as a standalone game, over a series of topics;1) Customization - Since the original Trackmania, players have always been able to customly paint cars without any set grids and whatnot. However, in Turbo, this isn't the case, as players customize their cars through set options that are gained by earning Gold Medals in the campaign. As much as this is a downgrade from previous installments, it finally gives a reason for those who just want to play the game to actually try the campaign. Would I call this a perk? That depends- for people such as myself, who have never been good at designing a car to begin with, yes. However, for those who can actually take the time to make a good-looking skin, no, this is a drastic loss.2) Local Multiplayer - Hotseat has been around since the original trackmania, and split-screen since Trackmania 2. However, also in every previous installment was Profiles- a big loss specifically to me. Profiles used to be kept with the game and were for all those who played the game to enter their profile, change their car, make maps, and etc. However, Trackmania Turbo gets rid of Profiles, but still has Hotseat, in a more of an arcade fashion, where each player, when it is there turn, has the option to change their name using 4 letters. A massive loss, in my mind, however, the gameplay of the new hotseat is nice. Split Screen hasn't changed much, so not much to say on that.3) Map Editor - A huge step up from the previous games. The Beginner mode, introduced in Nations & United Forever, helped people completely new to the game make maps with reasonably good detail in the background. Now, the difference between Normal mode and Advanced mode is one that I find perfectly fitting. For those who want to make perfect, amazing maps- Advanced mode is great, as it's completely barren from the start, and you can edit every little thing. For others who simply want a track to play on, Normal mode is very helpful, as you can build the map very quickly with various presets, and also have decoration filled in for you. Not to mention the landscapes are all as set templates. And the final amazing improvement to the Map Editor is the Random Track Generator- which I'm in love with. The Random Track Generator is literally an AI that pieces together the various presets from Normal Mode in a varying fashion each time. I'm still unsure as to what it prioritizes, but that makes the tracks even more fun.4) Campaign & Singleplayer - Realistically, the only difference between this and the previous games is that the campaign actually has a reason to be played now- for unlockables. However, on the downside, it forces you to play all 10 tracks of the previous difficulty & environment before moving to the next, unlike previous Trackmania games. Not much else to say here.5) Online Multiplayer - Being a part of the Nations/United Forever Dirty Deeds clan, I was playing multiplayer quite frequently on Forever. From what I can say, there's only a time attack mode for online so far, as compared to previous; Time Attack, Rounds, Team, Cup, etc. It's a bit of a let-down, but at the same time, most multiplayer servers from Forever were Time Attack anyways. Past this is also the stats for tracks, which people seemed to have valued. As much as I do miss seeing the world-wide fastest time on a track, it was a mod for Trackmania, never actually part of the game, so we can't really include it here. There's no more dedicated servers, which is a but upsetting, as it means everything is now hosted by people, BUT, it makes it much easier to set up a quick server for yourself and a few friends.There's a bit more to the game that I'm not putting here, but that's mainly because it's not really comparable with other installments, or I've yet to experience it myself. From how I've enjoyed the game so far, I do recommend Trackmania veterans, and newcomers, to play the game, as it certainly, at least for me, lives up to the hype I've had since July.

												This game is getting way more hate than it deserves.  Just going to start by getting that out of the way.  I've been playing Trackmania for over a decade, and I feel like I'm the only diehard Trackmania fan that isn't being blinded by nostalgic fluff.It's fast, it runs well, it looks nice, and the cars handle very well.  The physics for each pre-existing environment have been tweaked to varying degrees, most noticeable being Valley (I.E. Down and Dirty), where it doesn't feel practically impossible to turn on dirt without losing speed because you didn't have millimeter precision.  It feels much more fluid now than it did in TM2.New blocks have been added for each environment, which helps keep it from feeling too samey to TM2, and adds some new surprises to each environment.If there were one complaint I do overall agree with, it is the lack of leaderboards per track (I.E. Dedi's).  Although to a casual player, this would largely be a useless feature anyways, as Dedi boards only really tended to matter for high skill players, as they are the only ones that ever make it onto them.That aside, the game plays great, and in the end, that is really what matters.  This is a time trials game with ridiculous over the top car physics, and it excels at being just that.  Although I haven't had the chance to try them, the new local multiplayer modes all look like they'd be a blast to play with friends, although it'd be nice if a few of them were available for online play (Though I understand why they aren't, as the majority of them would be complete garbage with latency between players).Overall, this is a great spinoff of the Trackmania series (Yes, this is a spin off, targetted to console players, not a sequel for PC players, get over it).  It may be lacking some fluff that the PC crowd is used to, but that's all it's really lacking... fluff.  The game itself is fantastic and I'd recommend it to anyone who loves arcade racers.

												My favorite arcade racing game in 18 years! Super recommended!(Since F-Zero X and R4: Ridge Racer Type 4)My initial review had ended there already, but since I'm a little shocked about all the negative reviews and comments about this game, I decided to write some more...TMT is time trial based racing at its very best. The controls are responsive and nuanced, the track designs are outstanding, and there is a lot of content and variety, both online and offline. The fine developers at Nadeo have crafted a unique game with an abundance of imaginative features and ideas. It really succeeds to fill a void, that so many rather standardized modern racing games have left behind.The game can be quite hard, especially the Rollercoatser Lagoon setting, and to feel some frustration is part of what Trackmania is about. Still, Nadeo has achieved a balanced progression in the campaign mode, which always gives you enough rewards and incentives to continue. I'm usually not too much into super challenging games, but TMT is absolutely addicting.And the presentation of TMT is fantastic. A great color scheme evoking memories of 90's arcade racing, some of the coolest original cars and environments in a long time, and very nice signage and typography. While the later is not quite on the level of what Designers Republic did for the WipEout series, it does come pretty close sometimes. Many complaints here on Steam are targeted at the limited customization options compared to previous Trackmania games, but I find it hard to understand, why anyone would want to change any of those assets. The game achieves an amazing coherent art style, which is just a pure joy to experience.TMT is more focused and polished than any Trackmania game before, making it my favorite Trackmania experience by far. I'm very inclined to say that this is one of the best arcade racers of all time!
